section.title: Boot server setup
section.para: Installing OpenBSD on the ALIX.2D3 is a little more involved than installing on standard PC hardware, due to the lack of a video card or the ability to boot from CD-ROM (even from USB CD-ROM devices). Instead we will have to use the ALIX board's PXE boot capability to boot into the installer, by running a PXE boot server on the PC mentioned in .

Thankfully, the Fedora 18 desktop live CD is flexible enough to provide this temporary boot server without requiring any permanent changes to your PC. The server will run PXE (appropriately configured DHCP and TFTP) services, along with an FTP server for providing OpenBSD system sets to the installer without requiring the target system to be able to route out to the wider Internet.

section.title: Fedora packages
section.para: Boot the Fedora live CD and click on "Try Fedora." Ensure the system has a working Internet connection, then open a terminal and invoke yum to install prerequisite packages:
section.screen: fedora$ su fedora# yum install dnsmasq vsftpd uucp

section.title: OpenBSD installation files
section.para:
For PXE booting, you will need to serve the pxeboot bootstrap and bsd.rd ramdisk kernel via TFTP. Make a directory to serve as the TFTP root and copy these there from your favorite mirror:
If you've purchased an OpenBSD CD set, you can find the files there instead, of course.
section.screen: fedora# mkdir -p /var/tftp fedora# cd /var/tftp fedora# lftp lftp :~> open ftp3.usa.openbsd.org lftp ftp3.usa.openbsd.org:~> cd /pub/OpenBSD/5.2/i386 lftp ftp3.usa.openbsd.org:/pub/OpenBSD/5.2/i386> mget pxeboot bsd.rd lftp ftp3.usa.openbsd.org:/pub/OpenBSD/5.2/i386> quit fedora#
section.para: Once the installer is running from bsd.rd, it will need to fetch the OpenBSD system sets. So likewise, copy these into an FTP directory:
section.screen: fedora# mkdir -p /var/ftp/pub/OpenBSD/5.2/i386 fedora# cd /var/ftp/pub/OpenBSD/5.2/i386 lftp :~> open ftp3.usa.openbsd.org lftp ftp3.usa.openbsd.org:~> cd /pub/OpenBSD/5.2/i386 lftp ftp3.usa.openbsd.org:/pub/OpenBSD/5.2/i386> mget *.tgz lftp ftp3.usa.openbsd.org:/pub/OpenBSD/5.2/i386> quit fedora#

section.title: Host system configuration
section.para: As configured out of the box, certain Fedora system processes will get in the way of the PXE server: default SELinux policies will prevent dnsmasq from serving files from /var/tftp, firewall rules will hinder access to the DHCP service, and NetworkManager will interfere with the IP address configuration of your Ethernet interface. As this is only a live CD, it is simplest to just disable these problematic services and get on with it:
section.screen: fedora# setenforce 0 fedora# systemctl stop firewalld.service fedora# systemctl stop NetworkManager.service
section.para: If your computer accesses your LAN through its Ethernet port, disconnect it from your LAN now. Run this command to configure a static address on the PC's Ethernet interface, substituting your own interface's name in place of em1:
section.screen: fedora# ip link set up dev em1 fedora# ip addr change 192.168.2.1/24 dev em1

section.title: DHCP and TFTP server
section.para: Now you can start the DHCP and TFTP server.

section.title: PXE booting the ALIX
section.para: With your serial console ready, plug in the ALIX board's power adapter, and you should see the board begin to boot. Enter the following at the OpenBSD boot menu:
section.screen: boot> stty com0 115200 boot> set tty com0 boot> bsd.rd

section.title: Basic setup
section.para: When the OpenBSD ramdisk boots, you will be prompted with the choices: (I)nstall, (U)pgrade, or (S)hell? â€“ press the I key to begin the installer. Therein you will be asked a few preliminary questions.

step.para: Configure IPv4 on the vr0 interface, but skip IPv6 configuration for now.
Choose and enter a root password.
Opt to start sshd(8) and ntpd(8) by default.
Specify that you do not expect to run the X Window System. This will cause the machdep.allowaperature sysctl to be disabled, possibly improving your system's security.
Set the default console to com0.
Skip setting up a regular user account for now.

section.title: Partitioning
section.para: Next you will need to set up your disk partitions and slices. In fdisk(8), specify that you want to use the whole disk for OpenBSD. Then you will be brought to the BSD disk label editor.
Press P to view the disk's current BSD slices; you shouldn't see anything here except the "c" slice, which represents the entire disk. Use the A command to create the disk slice set shown in .

When that is done, press Q to quit the label editor, then press Y to confirm that you wish to write the new disk label. Confirm your way past any relevant warning messages, and the CF card will be partitioned and formatted for OpenBSD's installation.

section.title: Installation sets
section.para:
Next you will be asked where to find the OpenBSD installation sets: choose the default mechanism, http, and use the default OpenBSD mirror (or any other mirror of your choice). Make any desired changes to the default set selection and then proceed to the next stage of the installer.
I have heard it said that it is a good idea to install all of the OpenBSD sets if one wants to build packages from the ports tree, even if one does not intend to run X11. However, I have not found this to be necessary in my own experience.

Once the sets have been installed, you can shut down your Ubuntu PXE boot server and reboot the ALIX board into its new OpenBSD installation. You may also wish to disable PXE booting in the ALIX's BIOS while you are not using it.
